paper_abstract: In this paper, we firstly introduce two new classes of fuzzy implications generated from one-variable functions, called (f, g, boolean AND)- and (f, g, boolean OR)-implications, respectively. Then we give a series of necessary and sufficient conditions that these implications satisfy: left neutrality property, identity principle, ordering principle, law of contraposition, modus ponens and modus tollens, respectively. We also discuss the relations between (f, g, boolean AND)-implication ((f, g, boolean OR)-implications, respectively) and other known classes of fuzzy implications.
